lines.text: How old are you, anyway?
Don't ask. Old enough.
Thirty? That's the turning point in a woman's life. The time to decide whether to marry... or open your own bar.

[to Keiko]
Would you laugh if I proposed to you?

[Keiko appears uncomfortable, remains silent]
I know. No need to answer. I just wanted to say it once. Pretend I never said it. Bye.

Keiko walks through the Ginza district on her way to The Lilac Bar]
Bars in the daytime are like women without makeup.
I hate liquor, yet I drink my fill every night.
30 and midnight, the Ginza's 16,000 hostesses head home in droves. The best go by cab... the second-rate take the train... and the worst go off with their customers.

[Narrating]
Back home I felt tired, and a little drunk. My rent is 30,000 yen - a lot for one person. But for us Ginza hostesses, an apartment's a fashionable accessory... just like expensive clothes and perfume.
A woman shouldn't be loose. That's one rule I've followed.

You've heard of Nobuko at Club 8? She wouldn't even give in to a Cabinet member. But then she fell in love with a down-and-out guitarist. Now she works as a maid in a love hotel. I started as a busboy in the Ginza ten years ago. I've seen a lot like her.
What's your point?
Just sharing my experience.
Even tiny bars in the Ginza cost over a million.
Ask yourself if you want to spend the rest of your life working for others.
Just between us, I'm deep in debt. It's taking its toll... I borrowed so much to get started, that now I'm in a pinch.
[laughs]
Don't laugh. What'll you do?
I've decided to die. Isn't that a great idea? They say sleeping pills work quite well.

[Looking dismayed]
Yuri!
Just kidding. It'll be a staged suicide. I won't actually die. I'll just fake it to hold off the creditors. Shocked?
Not shocked... impressed.

[Narrating]
Women in the Ginza fought desperately for survival. It was a battle I couldn't afford to lose.
What a nice fragrance. What's your perfume?
Black Narcissus.

[Scolding Keiko]
Stop being so emotional. This is a bar. People pay to have a good time.
So what?
Listen to me! You get paid to show men a good time. If you don't like it, take off that kimono and work in an office... and starve!
You keep a fancy apartment instead of living at home.
That's not an extravagance.
Then what is it? Tell me!

Customers come to the Ginza for a taste of luxury. Satisfying that craving is what we're paid for. Apartments beyond our means, taxis, expensive perfumes - it all serves that purpose. Men wouldn't be interested if they knew I lived in a place like this.
Mother, how many times must I tell you? Kimonos aren't a luxury for me!
it's business!

That's right! Looking good means good customers. In the Ginza, appearance is everything. You wouldn't understand. I'm actually quite frugal. Flashy kimonos would get more attention, but I can't wear them in the daytime, so I buy plain ones instead. You have no right to call me extravagant!

[Angrily, to her mother]
Who'd ever want to work in a bar? Drinking 'til I'm sick, being a plaything for men... I haven't enjoyed a single day since I started. Even lying here, thoughts of bills torment my dreams. I'm miserable! But how else could I send you 20,000 a month? If you can find me a better job, tell me and I'll quit!
I never dreamed I'd become the wife of a factory owner.
Even when a woman's in your arms, you can never tell who she's really thinking of.
I love you, but I don't have the courage to break up my home. It may be selfish of me, but it's the truth.

[Narrating]
It had been a bleak ordeal, like a harsh winter. But the trees that line the streets can sprout new buds, no matter how cold the wind. I too must be just as strong as the winds that gust around me.
